Situation Text: You look at your budget and you realize you need to make some changes.  But all of the expenses seem necessary! What do you do?
Opt 1 Text: Eliminate all the entertainment…I need the money for my new shiny car! But what if people stop liking me because I never party! I can't lose my personality
Opt 1 Response Text: Great job saving money, unfortunately you became less popular which makes you sad :(
Opt 2 Text: Just work overtime later! I would rather sacrifice some time to make some more money than give up all my expensive things! (You gain an extra 400/month) (Happiness Meter (-1) every month)
Opt 2 Response Text: You may be getting extra money in the bank, but your hapiness decreases slightly every month because of how much extra time you need to spend working :(
Opt 3 Text: Get rid of that expensive clothing bill. My boyfriend loves my clothes…I don't want to make him upset. Cut the clothing cost to only 100 dollars
Opt 3 Response Text: Oh no! You went into depression because your boyfriend hates you without all your fashion

Situation Text: It's that time of year! Time to figure out your housing situation. You got one semester left, and you really want to finish strong and end with the same dorm you've had for four years now. But…..is it really the best option?
Opt 1 Text: Get the dorm! I can find money other ways but dorming has been one of the best experiences in my life. Get the dorm! Get the dorm!
Opt 1 Response Text: You love the dorm! you and your friends get to party all the time!
Opt 2 Text: But, with the amount of good friends I have, why not just get an apartment with four other friends? This could be a way cheaper option for me.
Opt 2 Response Text: Awesome! You made both a financial and personal smart decision! Wazah!
Opt 3 Text: Honestly, NJ isn't that big. I can just meet my friends from time to time. I say, COMMUTING is the best option. Nothing is cheaper than free…
Opt 3 Response Text: Even though you still spend time with your friends, you personally feel like a pathetic loser. Your hapiness goes down

Situation Text: CANCUNNNNNNNNNN! WHO DOESN'T LOVE AN AMAZING SUMMER RETREAT! Your friends are planning a summer vacation to cancun and they are begging you to join. It's always been your dream to go to cancun, and honestly, you could use a good picker uper from time to time.
Opt 1 Text: Skip the trip. I can always go to these kind of vacations after college when I'm making some real money at my full time job.
Opt 1 Response Text: Ah man! Coulda met a hot lifeguard or something like that. Maybe even coulda done some YOGA with him.
Opt 2 Text: 100 PERCENT YES, I need the trip to fix the rut I've been in. It's definitely worth the money.
Opt 2 Response Text: Woohooooo, the cancun trip was amazing...you met a couple hot life guards, you even got a hot YOGA date with one of them.
Opt 3 Text: N/A
Opt 3 Response Text: N/A

Situation Text: Your best friend approaches you with an investment opportunity. He lets you know that while this is EXTREMELY RISKY, there is a chance that you can get up to double your returns. What do you want to do?
Opt 1 Text: Yes, I will definitely invest. I'll put in _____ of my money
Opt 1 Response Text: See coin flip!
Opt 2 Text: No, I think I would rather just play it safe
Opt 2 Response Text: You're so boring
Opt 3 Text: N/A
Opt 3 Response Text: N/A

Situation Text: Your college advisor approaches you to inform you that there has been a change with the dining plan rules. You can now choose to continue on the same dining plan, or opt to fend for your own. What do you do?
Opt 1 Text: Yeah, I'm sick of this dining food. I would rather cook by myself. Anyways I eat out a lot, so I can just continue that a bit more, and cook for myself a bit too.
Opt 1 Response Text: Gordon Ramsay replies to your instagram post "Amazing eggs benedict, you are a star"
Opt 2 Text: I think I'll stick to the dining plan, but thanks!
Opt 2 Response Text: Cool
Opt 3 Text: You know what, know that I'm thinking about it, I think I should cut my outside dining too. I'll stick to the home food diet.
Opt 3 Response Text: You're always jealous seeing your favorite people go to MCC campus for the delicious chicken tenders. Your happiness decreases

Situation Text: Graduation is approaching which means only ONE THING: GRADUATION PARTY. You have been looking forward to this for a long time and this is one event you just can't forget. The Graduation Party to host will cost $250. Remember, starting next month, you would like to make your downpayment for the car, and begin to make monthly payments on it as well.
Opt 1 Text: Yeah, do the graduation party…it's something that I just can't skip.
Opt 1 Response Text: WOW! THAT WAS AMAZING. I think you even got a phone number from this cute guy named Jatin. Can't wait for what the future has in store
Opt 2 Text: Eh, I'm not sure if I have the money, but I'll pick up a second job as well (+200/ just this month). I really need to have this and I'm willing for short term sadness for long term happiness
Opt 2 Response Text: You worked hard, and you managed to get the party without spending too much money! Good job! To top it all of, you got a phone number from a cute guy named Jatin ;)
Opt 3 Text: I'm tired and burnt out. If I had the money I would spend it, but honestly I'll try to enjoy my friends' parties. There's nothing I can do.
Opt 3 Response Text: You're a loser to yourself. Your happiness decreases because your jealous of all the other parties. You even had to deal with your friend getting a cute guys phone number who you really wanted to talk to. Oh well, I guess Jatin wasnt the man for you

Situation Text: It's time to start working! You graduated and you are going to start your job next month. You need to put that downpayment for the car, and start with your monthly payments next month. Your employer calls you and tells you that your monthly salary will be 3500/month. Figure out a plan so that you will be able to survive financially. The monthly payments for the car will be 500/month
Opt 1 Text: I can't afford the car yet. Unfortunately, I am going to need to take the bus. The bus costs 40/day for roundtrip. This means a monthly cost of 800.
Opt 1 Response Text: Bummer! Guess saving money is harder than you thought. Shoulda have been studying instead of partying. Suxks
Opt 2 Text: Yes! Buy the car. Put down the downpayment for 3000.
Opt 2 Response Text: Congrats! You got the car! With the car, your opportunities are endless, and you've proven to yourself that you're financialy capable of success
Opt 3 Text: I guess I'm ready for the car. But I also need to cut some costs to make some room for the monthly payments. Cut costs of two items by 50 percent.
Opt 3 Money Change: -300 (add the cost of two items that they select)
Opt 3 Response Text: You barely made it. But good job i guess.

Situation Text: Time to save! The first thing that you see is that your parents are sucking 2000 of your money every month. You love your parents to death, but 2000? Is it really necessary? I think it's time to change something.
Opt 1 Text: On second thought, my parents mean the world to me, I need to make sure they are living luxuriously even if it is at my own exepnse. Keep everything how it is.
Opt 1 Response Text: Even though your parents are happy, this is still a financial burden on you, so your happiness score goes down just a bit.
Opt 2 Text: I can't keep letting them live as luxurious as possible, but at the same time, I don't just want to ignore them. Move them to a cheaper, but still very nice, old age home. Payments are only 1000 a month
Opt 2 Response Text: Youre super excited that the burden is reduced. In fact, even your parents understand, and that makes them happy that you wouldnt leave them hanging out to dry no matter what
Opt 3 Text: I'll take care of them again once I have the money. Let them know that they are moving to the state home where payments are only 500 dollars a month.
Opt 3 Response Text: You may have saved money, but it kills you to see your parents in the state home. They are unhappy, and so are you. This is not how they wanted to live luxuriously in their retirement.

Situation Text: 750 for a daycare center! That's outrageous. I mean, what are they serving there, steak and eggs?
Opt 1 Text: Let's move to a little cheaper. It may be a little bit farther from home, but at least you're saving money on the daycare. Pay $300 every month instead.
Opt 1 Response Text: You're kid is kind of nervous about the new place. Because of that, he's been annoying you all night, and you barely got any sleep. Happiness goes down.
Opt 2 Text: Keep the daycare. You're child's happiness should go over everything. You'll figure out another way to save the money.
Opt 2 Response Text: Thank god you didnt change. Your child cried just at the prospect of changing daycares. Because he's happy, you're also happy
Opt 3 Text: Come home early every day and have a nanny take care of your son until the morning. Pay $100/ month and you will lose some money due to the less hours at work.
Opt 3 Response Text: Your losing time at work which means less time in front of your boss. He's becoming unhappy which means so are you

Situation Text: Every month you are losing $300 to an investment that could be going towards your saving for your child. Who knows if it will ever pay off, but every month, you trust in your guts. However, time is running out. What do you do?
Opt 1 Text: Keep the investment. Who knows if it will ever pay off.
Opt 1 Response Text: Great choice! It's always wise to keep your money growing in investments. Let your money work for you!
Opt 2 Text: Keep the money. You're going to need it so that you can continue saving your money.
Opt 2 Response Text: Oh no! Maybe you should have kept the investment. 300 dollars today could mean more money in your pocket later
Opt 3 Text: Maybe try keeping the investment but decrease it by $150. At least you're saving and investing that way.
Opt 3 Response Text: Great compromise! Keeping half of the investment money and then investing the other half...at least this way you are still investing SOME money.

Situation Text: You're looking at your budget, and you see that you are spending almost 1000 dollars on food every month. You realize that food is important, but as logn as your child eats well, and you and your husband eat modestly, everything should work out fine. What do you do?
Opt 1 Text: Keep food the same. You're going to need it to succesfully save enough money for private school.
Opt 1 Response Text: Hoorah! Amazing choice. Food is a necessity. You always want to cut down your wants not your needs.
Opt 2 Text: Reduce the food. You need to save any money that you can. Decrease your food spending to only $600/month
Opt 2 Response Text: Uh oh! Hopefully the decreased food doesn't impact your thinking. Your happiness goes down.
Opt 3 Text: N/A
Opt 3 Response Text: N/A

Situation Text: Shoot! All this time you've been saving, but slowly you've been losing money because you have to spend more time with your kdis and your wife. You decide to work on a side hussle instead, to make a couple $100 for this month.
Opt 1 Text: Do the side hussle. You're going to need all the money that you can get.
Opt 1 Response Text: Nice! Made some extra cash, but not gonna lie, working so hard took its toll
Opt 2 Text: I can't work on the side! I'm not good enough to be an entrepreneur. I honestly don't have the time or the patience.
Opt 2 Response Text: You may be more happy, but you definitely could have used those couple hundered dollars.
Opt 3 Text: N/A
Opt 3 Response Text: N/A

Situation Text: The private school enrollment is coming up very soon. Looking at your budget, you're not sure if you have enough money to last for a couple months of payments of 300 dollars.
Opt 1 Text: Option 1: Forgoe this month's IRA contribution. Saving for retirement is important, but does one month really matter?
Opt 1 Response Text: Not a smart move. Your happiness decreases a lot because this eventually develops into a habit, and you are not well off for your retirement. No matter what, try to fulfill short term goals, while leaving your LONG TERM GOALS untouched. Long term > Short Term. Develop good habits early on to avoid them in the future
Opt 2 Text: Option 2: Don't forget about this month's IRA contribution. You can take a loan if you need so, but retirement savings are really important.
Opt 2 Response Text: Good choice! No matter what, try to fulfill short term goals, while leaving your LONG TERM GOALS untouched. Long term > Short Term. Develop good habits early on to avoid them in the future
Opt 3 Text: Option 3: Skip a credit card debt payment instead.
Opt 3 Response Text: Not a good decision. Try to pay your minimum credit card payments as best as possible. You don't want your interest to build up to a point where you don't have enough money to pay it off

Situation Text: Time to pay! You have saved long and hard for this moment. It's finally time to enroll you child in private school. Go ahead! Reach for the stars! Also, don't forget to book the vacation for this summer!
Opt 1 Text: PAY THE DOWNPAYMENT AND THE FIRST MONTHLY PAYMENT. GREAT JOB SAVING THE MONEY.
Opt 1 Response Text: Great Job! You're a financial Wizard. Ka-ching!
Opt 2 Text: I simply don't have the money. I think I'm just going to have to pass on the vacation :(
Opt 2 Response Text: Awe no! You were unable to take the trip. Happiness definitely decreases. Hopefully in the future, you'll be able to save better.
Opt 3 Text: Just keep him in the regular school. I can't afford anything. I am horrible.
Opt 3 Response Text: You were not able to meet your goal...poor Derrel...

Situation Text: As you start glancing at your budget, the biggest number that sticks out to you right away is the food. You're spending a lot of money for food, and you're not that big of a fan of Wendy's 4 for 4 anyways.
Opt 1 Text: Keep the food. You're going to need the food to fuel you for the upcoming project at work. Plus, you don't even have the time to cook at home anyways. I guess you could take off work, but then it might be hard to go for that bonus you're really hoping will come through
Opt 1 Response Text: Lets see how that works out.... Happiness Stays the same
Opt 2 Text: Go out to eat less. You might have to leave work earlier so you can actually make a meal for yourself, but it's worth the dollars you save in the long run.
Opt 2 Response Text: Wow! You're losing weight too. Good job, wendy's is no longer gonna get the best of you. Happiness definitely increases
Opt 3 Text: N/A
Opt 3 Response Text: N/A

Situation Text: As you predicted, a project has popped up and your boss has specifically requested for you and your main competitor, Sal, to work overtime on this project. You know this will take some of your time, but at the same time, it can give you the boost you need to save up for your wedding. What do you do?
Opt 1 Text: Take the overtime. It can help build a better relationship with you and your boss, and maybe even get that promotion and bonus. (can't choose this if you chose Month 1 option 2)
Opt 1 Response Text: You and your boss are slowly getting closer! Good strategy dude. But even then, its still extra work so your happiness decreases
Opt 2 Text: Reject the offer. You simply don't have time, and maybe you can focus on other options of making money passively.
Opt 2 Response Text: Time to turn full on entrepreneur. Your happiness stays the same because nothign really happened
Opt 3 Text: Ask to work from home. You still get the money, but you may not be able to develop the same relationship you could have by working late in office.
Opt 3 Response Text: I feel like Sal is getting closer! I really hope my work is impressing the boss! Your stress causes your happiness to go down.

Situation Text: One day you're on the phone and your aunt tells you that you should cut a dollar or two by getting rid of the health insurance. You probably won't hurt yourself in the next month or two, and you can always just use your fiancees medical expertise. Just risk it, she says.
Opt 1 Text: She's crazy, don't risk it.
Opt 1 Response Text: Good choice! Health insurance is always important
Opt 2 Text: Do it, why not? What's the WORST that can happen.
Opt 2 Response Text: You're living life on the edge bro, be careful
Opt 3 Text: Your aunt also presents you with another health insurance that is significantly cheaper. However, you don't really trust this place as it looks kind of sketchy. (50/month)
Opt 3 Response Text: You're a little worried about the place, but you're very happy about the saved money. So overall, lets see how this plays out.

Situation Text: Your friends offer you a ride to work, as one of them moved to the neighborhood recently. That being said, you don't want to impose as a hassle.
Opt 1 Text: Take the ride. Any money matters
Opt 1 Response Text: Hmm. You're friends are getting kind of annoyed at you that you can never help them but that they always help you. Happiness goes down
Opt 2 Text: Don't. You don't want everyone to think of you as a hassle.
Opt 2 Response Text: You get rides occasionally. Good enough for me. Happiness stays the same.
Opt 3 Text: N/A
Opt 3 Response Text: N/A

Situation Text: Promotion Time! You know it's right about the time when the boss is going to be handing out promotions and bonuses, and you can't wait for all your hardwork to pay off. Just to make sure that you tip him over the edge, you want to take to him to a $200 restaraunt.
Opt 1 Text: Take him, gotta make sure that we get that promotion.
Opt 1 Response Text: Wow, great dinner, you loved the experience. You even filled up on some caviar. Your happiness increases
Opt 2 Text: Just leave it. You're confident in your workign ability.
Opt 2 Response Text: Potentially bad mistake. In corporate scenarios like these, it's always better to do some but kissing
Opt 3 Text: Get him $100 gift basket and call it a day.
Opt 3 Response Text: The gift basket looks really cool. Your happiness increases. You even swipe a chocolate or two from the basket...he won't ever know

Situation Text: The wedding is coming up really soon, and as such, you want to be prepared for the money that you're going to have to pay. But alas, no matter how hard you try, you can't figure out another way to reduce the money that you're spending. You call up the wedding planner and ask if there's any way to cut the cost. She tells you that there is a similar location for 3,000 dollars cheaper. What do you do?
Opt 1 Text: Take the place. Your fiancee will understand and you will save a lot of money
Opt 1 Response Text: Dang it, you won't have that perfect wedding. It's okay, as long as you promise to name your kids Sibhitherumeni Selvamanickam Ramadoss, you're sure that your wife will be fine
Opt 2 Text: No way. There's no way we can just ruin our dream wedding
Opt 2 Response Text: Great choice! You've always been looking for this day. Plus, this way, at least you wont have to name your child Sibhitherumeni Selvamanickam Ramadoss like your wife wants you to
Opt 3 Text: N/A
Opt 3 Response Text: N/A

Situation Text: It's that time! Time to put down the money for that wedding you've been looking forward to so much.
Opt 1 Text: PUT DOWN THE MONEY! You have it and you're ready
Opt 1 Response Text: Great Job! You're a financial Wizard. Ka-ching!
Opt 2 Text: I simply don't have the money. I'm going to need to take a loan…
Opt 2 Response Text: Oh no! Guess you're going to have to deal with a loan. This can be annoying, especially because of those pesky interest payments. Well, suxks
Opt 3 Text: N/A
Opt 3 Response Text: N/A
